name: Diphenhydramine (Benadryl)
summary: A first-generation antihistamine used for allergy symptoms, insomnia, motion sickness, and mild anxiety, with notable sedative properties.
description: Diphenhydramine is a first-generation H1 receptor antagonist with anticholinergic and sedative properties. It is commonly used for allergic reactions, hay fever, the common cold, and short-term management of insomnia. It can also be used for motion sickness prevention, extrapyramidal symptom (EPS) management, and mild anxiety. Due to strong sedation and anticholinergic effects, it is not generally recommended for chronic use in older adults.

items: Symptomatic relief of allergic rhinitis and urticaria
Prevention and treatment of motion sickness
Management of drug-induced parkinsonism and extrapyramidal symptoms

sections.text: Competitively inhibits histamine at H1 receptors, reducing symptoms of allergy. Also exhibits anticholinergic and sedative properties via central nervous system effects.

adult.allergy: 25–50 mg orally every 4–6 hours as needed (max 300 mg/day)
adult.motion-sickness: 25–50 mg orally 30 minutes before exposure, then every 4–6 hours as needed

sections.pediatric: Varies by indication and age; avoid in children under 2 years unless directed by physician
sections.geriatric: Use lowest effective dose; avoid chronic use due to anticholinergic burden

sections.text: Onset: 15–60 minutes orally; Duration: 4–6 hours (up to 8 hours for sedation)

other: Avoid chronic use in elderly due to increased risk of cognitive decline and falls
May cause significant sedation and impair driving ability
Caution in patients with narrow-angle glaucoma, urinary retention, or asthma

items: Effectiveness for allergy or sleep symptoms

sections.lactation: May cause sedation/irritability in infant; use caution
sections.pediatrics: Avoid in children <2 years unless prescribed; risk of paradoxical excitation
sections.geriatrics: Avoid chronic use; increased risk of cognitive impairment

sections.text: No formal taper required; discontinue if side effects outweigh benefits.

items: Not recommended as a long-term sleep aid due to tolerance and anticholinergic burden
Commonly available OTC for allergies and sleep
Use with caution when combined with other sedating medications
